item.title: bus-topology
item.description: The bus topology consist of connecting the devices of a computer network to a terminated central cable. In this way, all devices are capable of see all the data transmitted trough the cable, but only the recipients of each piece of data will receive it.

item.title: client-server
item.description: Being the opposite of peer-to-peer, the Client-Server network architecture consists of a server that manages all resources (and the access to them) in the network and the client that tries to access the resources from the first.

item.title: computer-networks
item.description: Basically, a computer network is the connection of two or more computers in a way they can share resources, Internet connection and devices.

item.title: data-collision
item.description: A data collision consists of two or more hosts trying to communicate in the same time, causing its transmitted data to colide and get lost.

item.title: fault-tolerance
item.description: The fault tolerance property consists of computer systems reducing fault impacts on itself by responding to adverse conditions, frequently resolving it.

item.title: hosts
item.description: Although the word host is used today for referring to any network device, in the context of comptia-network-plus it is defined as any network device with an ip-address.

item.title: hub_and_spoke-topology
item.description: The hub-and-spoke topology, also knows as star topology, consists of the devices of the network being connected through a central point (which can be a hub, an access point, etc).

item.title: hybrid-mesh-topology
item.description: The hybrid mesh topology is a variation of the mesh-topology, consisting of interconnections between some devices, for redundancy, and other types of physical topologies connected to it.

item.title: hybrid-topology
item.description: The hybrid topology consists, basically, of the blend of two or more physical-topologies, being it in the physical layer or in the logical one.

item.title: learning-how-to-learn
item.description: In the field of infosec, it is necessary to keep learning and quickly, as penetration testers must have wide and deep knowledge in various areas.

item.title: local-area-network
item.description: Local Area Network (LAN) is a type of computer network restricted geographically by a location as a house, a building or a school.

item.title: mesh-topology
item.description: The mesh topology consists of a network where each device is connected to all others, in a shape of a complete graph.

item.title: metropolitan-area-network
item.description: A Metropolitan Area Network (MAN) is a type of network that is geographically expanded to cover a metropolitan area. Generally its interconnections use in-ground optical-fiber cables, which can be very cost-effective for high internet speed.

item.title: multiprotocol-label-switching
item.description: Multiprotocol Label Switching (MPLS) is a popular protocol used in wide-area-network. It assigns labels to data that will be sent to the MPLS network (cloud).

item.title: peer-to-peer
item.description: The peer-to-peer (P2P) network architecture consists in a number of computers connected to each other, each one with the possibility to act as client/server to the others.

item.title: physical-topologies
item.description: The physical topology of a computer network defines the position of its devices and connections between them. references

item.title: point_to_multipoint-topology
item.description: The point-to-multipoint topology consists of, basically, a relation of one endpoint (that can be a router, hub, switch, antenna, etc) to $n$ other endpoints.

item.title: point_to_point-topology
item.description: A point-to-point topology consists of the direct connection between any two hosts, being this connection physical or logical. references

item.title: ring-topology
item.description: The ring topology consists of the devices of the network being connected to a circular bus. In other words, the data flows from a computer to the next in a circle, until it gets back to the source.

item.title: servers
item.description: Powerful computer that serves another machines in the network. Although a unique server perform multiple jobs, it is recommended to specialize each machine so the network performs better.

item.title: software_defined-wide-area-networks
item.description: The Software-Defined Wide Area Network (SDWAN) is a type of virtual wide-area-network where attributes as connectivity, devices and services can be managed by software in real time.

item.title: storage-area-networks
item.description: Storage Area Networks are used by storage systems. It have specific protocols as fibre-channel and iscsi. Also, the hardware this type of network uses is specifically designed for “carry storage traffic”.

item.title: wide-area-networks
item.description: As the name suggests, a Wide Area Network (WAN) is a type of network that covers a larger geographic space. Because of its size, it is slower than local-area-network and the hosts can choose to be disconnected from it (while in LANs they are either connected to it or not).

item.title: workgroups
item.description: In a local-area-network, workgroups are “small logical zones” where computers are physically connected to the same network segment. references

item.title: workstations
item.description: Powerful computer with more than one CPU available for end users in a network. Technically, it is not a client machine.
